questions.text: A young adult aged 23 comes to the RAP and reports they will lose their housing in 10 days. What should the assessor do?

options.A: Complete a Housing Triage Tool immediately
options.B: Refer them to prevention services only
options.C: Tell them to return when they're actually homeless
options.D: Complete an HTT as they're eligible as an at-risk young adult

questions.explanation: Young adults (18-24) who are at risk of homelessness within 14 days are eligible for CE services.

questions.text: What is the first step a Housing Assessor should take at a Regional Access Point before completing a triage tool?
questions.explanation: RAP staff should discuss diversion options and employment navigation before completing a triage tool to assess for options outside of CE.

questions.text: Within what timeframe must Housing Assessors complete all Housing Triage Tools in HMIS?
questions.explanation: Housing Assessors must complete all Housing Triage Tools in HMIS within 48 hours of when the information was first collected.

questions.text: Sarah fled domestic violence and doesn't want her information in HMIS. How should the assessor proceed?

options.A: Tell her she cannot receive services without consent
options.B: Enter her as a de-identified profile and send encrypted email to CE
options.C: Enter her information anyway for her safety
options.D: Refer her to a different agency

questions.explanation: Personal information is not entered in HMIS for people fleeing DV. Enter as de-identified and send encrypted email to alex.ebrahimi@kcrha.org with subject 'De-Identified Household'.

questions.text: A family consists of mom (age 35), dad (age 37), and children ages 16, 18, and 8. How many HMIS consents are needed?
questions.explanation: Parents sign for minors under 18 (ages 16 and 8). The three adults (mom, dad, and 18-year-old) each sign for themselves.

questions.text: Which households should be entered as group enrollments in Coordinated Entry?
questions.explanation: For Coordinated Entry enrollments, only families with minor children at the time of assessment will be entered as a group.

questions.text: John was in jail for 4 months. He was homeless before entering jail. Is he eligible for CE?

options.A: Yes, he meets institutional stay requirements
options.C: Only if he has a disability

questions.explanation: To be eligible after exiting an institution, the stay must be 90 days or less if they were homeless before entering. 4 months exceeds this limit.

questions.text: What is the minimum number of assessments a Housing Assessor must complete annually to maintain HMIS access?
questions.explanation: Housing Assessors must conduct at least 1 Housing Triage Tool per month or 12 assessments per year to maintain assessment access in HMIS.

questions.text: Where must all CE assessments and services be entered in HMIS?

options.B: In the Coordinated Entry System Agency

questions.explanation: All trained Housing Assessors must switch to the Coordinated Entry System Agency in HMIS for all Coordinated Entry related work.

questions.text: Maria identifies as a Veteran. What additional document should the assessor obtain?
questions.explanation: Veterans should sign a Department of Veterans Affairs ROI so they can be discussed at the Veteran's By Name List Case Conferencing meeting.

questions.text: How many questions are in the current Housing Triage Tool (HTT)?
questions.explanation: Coordinated Entry assessors will complete a two-question Housing Triage Tool.

questions.text: Tom refuses to sign HMIS consent. Can he still receive CE services?
questions.explanation: Households that refuse consent can still receive services. They're entered as de-identified profiles with only a unique identifier number.

questions.text: What is the maximum error rate allowed for CE assessors according to data quality standards?
questions.explanation: CE Trainers must ensure assessor error rates stay under 5% through regular review of data quality reports and dashboards.

questions.text: A 17-year-old arrives alone at the RAP seeking housing. What should the assessor do?

options.C: Explain they're not eligible without a parent/guardian

questions.explanation: Unaccompanied minors (under 18 without parent/guardian) are NOT eligible for CE services independently.

questions.text: When should a new Current Living Situation (CLS) assessment be created?

options.C: Each time you provide a CE service or update HTT

questions.explanation: Create a new CLS assessment at enrollment start and each time you provide a coordinated entry service, start a new HTT, or update an existing HTT.

questions.text: What is chronic homelessness defined as?

options.B: 12 consecutive months OR 4+ occasions totaling 12 months over 3 years, with disability

questions.explanation: An individual is chronically homeless if homeless for 12 consecutive months+, or 4+ occasions totaling 12 months over 3 years, with a documented disability.

questions.text: The assessor accidentally clicked 'Private' on an assessment. What is the consequence?

options.B: CE staff cannot see it and household won't be referred

questions.explanation: Never select 'Private' in any part of HMIS. If made private, CE staff won't be able to see information and the household will never be referred to housing.

questions.text: How long is the default ROI expiration period in King County?
questions.explanation: The End Date will default to seven years from the start date. This is the correct default date for King County.

questions.text: For whom should services be entered in the Coordinated Entry System Agency?
questions.explanation: Services only need to be entered for the Head of Household.

questions.text: Since October 2020, how does CE prioritize households?
questions.explanation: Since October 2020, CE prioritizes households based on COVID-19 disproportionate impact factors determined by Seattle King County Public Health.

questions.text: What training must be completed before receiving HMIS access?
questions.explanation: All Clarity Human Services (HMIS) users must complete Clarity General Training before being granted database access.

questions.text: A client completed a VI-SPDAT 8 months ago. Do they need a new Housing Triage Tool?
questions.explanation: Households with a Housing Triage Tool or VI-SPDAT completed prior to the change don't need to complete a new HTT.

questions.text: What is the minimum diversion service duration according to CE guidelines?
questions.explanation: Diversion has 30 days to complete services, with a minimum duration of 90 days for the diversion period.

questions.text: Which agency is the Coordinating Entity for CE in King County?
questions.explanation: King County Regional Homelessness Authority (KCRHA) is the Coordinating Entity for CE.

questions.text: A couple without children needs CE services. How should they be enrolled?
questions.explanation: Single adults and couples without children receive individual enrollments. Only families with minor children use group enrollments.

questions.text: What phone number should assessors call for Clarity/HMIS technical support?
questions.explanation: Contact Bitfocus helpdesk at (206) 444-4001 ext. 2 for HMIS/Clarity support and new user accounts.

questions.text: How often must Housing Assessors attend refresher training?
questions.explanation: All Housing Assessors must attend at least one Assessor Refresher training in a 12-month period.

questions.text: When completing electronic signature for ROI, what is the correct sequence?
questions.explanation: For electronic ROI: have client sign, click Apply, then Save, then Add Record to complete the process.

questions.text: What happens if a household has a Housing Triage Tool but hasn't updated info in months?

options.B: They remain potentially eligible for prioritization
options.C: They must complete a new HTT
options.D: They go to bottom of list

questions.explanation: Households with existing HTTs remain potentially eligible for prioritization as long as they remain active in the CE System Agency Program.

questions.text: What document helps Veterans get on the By Name List for case conferencing?
questions.explanation: Veterans who sign a Department of Veterans Affairs ROI can be discussed at the Veteran's By Name List Case Conferencing meeting.
